title: New Punggol and Pasir Ris-Changi GRCs in north-east, following rapid population growth | The Straits Times

parsed_web_results.title: New Punggol and Pasir Ris-Changi GRCs in north-east, following rapid population growth | The Straits Times
parsed_web_results.content:
SINGAPORE – Two new group representation constituencies have been formed in the north-east – the area with the largest increase in the number of voters since the last general election.

The existing five-member Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC will be split into two new four-member GRCs, with a new Punggol GRC created by carving out estates in Punggol and merging those with Punggol West SMC.

Farther east, Pasir Ris-Changi GRC will take in the remaining estates in Pasir Ris and some of the easternmost parts of East Coast GRC.

The Electoral Boundaries Review Committee (EBRC) detailed these boundary changes in its report released on March 11, nearly two months after it was formed on Jan 22.

Compared with past reports, the committee set out in greater detail its rationale for the boundary changes, which the Government has accepted.

The changes will take effect at the next general election, widely expected by the middle of the year.

![Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC, helmed by Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean, will be split into two new four-member GRCs. Punggol West SMC, which was won by PAP’s Ms Sun Xueling (in red) in 2020, will form part of the new Punggol GRC in the next election.](https://cassette.sphdigital.com.sg/image/straitstimes/f7ea6a0d739302ded18ecade5ec1a95a9f2bafa1777db4a9b95e1938854c35fc?w=860)

The number of voters has increased to 2,753,226 as at Feb 1, 2025, up from 2,651,435 at the 2020 General Election.

This increase was not evenly distributed across the island, the committee noted.

There was higher growth in Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC, Sembawang GRC, Tampines GRC, Hong Kah North SMC and Potong Pasir SMC due to population shifts and new housing developments, it said.

The two new GRCs in the north-east are largely drawn from the existing Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC, which made its debut on the electoral map in 2001.

This constituency has seen large population growth in the last five years, given the new Build-To-Order estates in Punggol such as Northshore Residences I and II.

It will continue growing, with more housing developments in the pipeline.

In 2020, it had 161,952 voters. This grew to 184,593 voters as at Feb 1.

![Goh Yan Han](https://cassette.sphdigital.com.sg/image/straitstimes/9c38e9110e20ae842e1572a6a99ef79b26843c3481a74dc41d2da5270a042de5)

The EBRC hence recommended that the Punggol area of the constituency – roughly demarcated by looking north of the Sungei Serangoon Park Connector – merge with Punggol West SMC to form the new Punggol GRC.

This will combine some 96,825 voters in Punggol with 26,732 voters from the single-member constituency for a total of 123,557 voters.

“This will also better reflect the identity of the estates in Punggol town,” said the committee.

The remaining polling districts from Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC will merge with the Loyang and Flora estates from East Coast GRC.

This new Pasir Ris-Changi GRC will have 100,639 voters – 87,768 from Pasir Ris-Punggol and 12,871 from East Coast.

The East Coast polling districts that come under this new constituency are those around Changi Airport and Changi Prison Complex.

Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC has been won by the People’s Action Party (PAP) with vote shares between 64 per cent and 73 per cent over the years. Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean, who anchors the GRC now, has contested there since 2001.

In 2020, it saw a three-cornered fight with the Singapore Democratic Alliance and Peoples Voice, where the PAP came away with a 64.16 per cent victory.

Punggol West SMC, a one-term constituency, was won by PAP’s Ms Sun Xueling with 60.98 per cent of the vote in 2020 against the Workers’ Party’s (WP) Ms Tan Chen Chen.

It had been carved out of Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC then, reducing the six-member constituency to five.

WP may look to contest Punggol GRC in the upcoming election, based on its activity in the area so far.

article_body.content: SINGAPORE – Two new group representation constituencies have been formed in the north-east – the area with the largest increase in the number of voters since the last general election.
The existing five-member Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC will be split into two new four-member GRCs, with a new Punggol GRC created by carving out estates in Punggol and merging those with Punggol West SMC.
Farther east, Pasir Ris-Changi GRC will take in the remaining estates in Pasir Ris and some of the easternmost parts of East Coast GRC.
The Electoral Boundaries Review Committee (EBRC) detailed these boundary changes in its report released on March 11, nearly two months after it was formed on Jan 22.
Compared with past reports, the committee set out in greater detail its rationale for the boundary changes, which the Government has accepted.
The changes will take effect at the next general election, widely expected by the middle of the year.
The number of voters has increased to 2,753,226 as at Feb 1, 2025, up from 2,651,435 at the 2020 General Election.

search_results.title: Voter Turnout in Presidential Elections - The American Presidency Project
search_results.content: Voter Turnout in Presidential Elections | The American Presidency Project The classic attempt to define the voting age population for the 19th century is by Walter Dean Burnham, “The Turnout Problem” in Elections American Style ed., Reichley (Brookings:  Washington D.C., 1987)  Burnham published only the turnout ratio, not his actual estimate of the voting age population! The US Elections Project data are also based on census and survey reports. Among their data is a series reporting the total number of persons "registered and eligible to vote."  For 2016, the sum of the individual county numbers, for counties with data in the US is 185,714,229--a number 15% greater than the CPS estimate for the same year and election.

search_results.title: GE2025: Extensive changes to electoral boundaries due to population ...
search_results.content: “Due to population shifts and new housing developments, some EDs (electoral divisions) such as Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC, Sembawang GRC, Tampines GRC, Hong Kah North SMC and Potong Pasir SMC have experienced higher growth than others,” it said. The Punggol estates in Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC were hence carved out and merged with Punggol West SMC to form a new four-member Punggol GRC, the EBRC said. “The committee also recommended reducing the size of Ang Mo Kio GRC, which has the most electors of any ED, by carving out some polling districts to form a new Jalan Kayu SMC,” the EBRC said. “Even with the Tengah estates being absorbed into Chua Chu Kang GRC, the remaining Hong Kah North SMC, comprising Bukit Batok West estates, is still too big and growing,” said the EBRC.

search_results.title: New Punggol and Pasir Ris-Changi GRCs in north-east, following rapid ...
search_results.content: The existing five-member Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC will be split into two new four-member GRCs, with a new Punggol GRC created by carving out estates in Punggol and merging those with Punggol West SMC. There was higher growth in Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC, Sembawang GRC, Tampines GRC, Hong Kah North SMC and Potong Pasir SMC due to population shifts and new housing developments, it said. This new Pasir Ris-Changi GRC will have 100,639 voters – 87,768 from Pasir Ris-Punggol and 12,871 from East Coast. With the changes to the Jurong area, a new Jurong Central SMC will be formed to maintain the new Jurong East-Bukit Batok GRC’s number of voters at a level suitable for a five-member constituency.

search_results.title: Flawed Calculation Behind False Claim of Fraudulent Votes
search_results.content: President Donald Trump and tens of thousands of others have shared a false claim on social media that there were “13 MILLION” more votes cast in the 2020 election than eligible voters who participated. In the latest of an unrelenting series of falsehoods on social media about the presidential election, a viral story is erroneously claiming that there were “13 MILLION” more votes counted in the election than the number of eligible voters who participated. “REVEALED: ‘Simple Math’ Shows Biden Claims 13 MILLION More Votes Than There Were Eligible Voters Who Voted in 2020 Election,” its headline reads. But as we said, the Washington Post story estimated that 66.2% of the voting-eligible population (around 239.2 million people, according to the United States Elections Project) voted, not 66.2% of registered voters.

fact_check.explanation: The given text states a specific number of voters but lacks context or a reliable source to verify its accuracy. It does not align with factual voter turnout data provided by official sources like PolitiFact or Reuters, which indicate significantly larger numbers for voter participation in 2020. Without corroboration, this information risks being misleading.

search_results.title: GE2025 electoral boundaries announced: 15 SMCs and 18 GRCs
search_results.content: SINGAPORE - Major changes ahead of Singapore’s next general election will see the creation of one more group representation constituency (GRC) and an additional single-seat ward, bringing the total to 18 GRCs and 15 single-member constituencies (SMC). Explaining its recommendations, the Electoral Boundaries Review Committee (EBRC) said in its report that voter numbers have grown significantly in Pasir Ris-Punggol, Sembawang and Tampines GRCs, as well as the single seats of Hong Kah North and Potong Pasir. Meanwhile, a new five-member Jurong East-Bukit Batok GRC will take in polling districts from the existing Jurong GRC, as well as parts of three SMCs which have been taken off the map – Bukit Batok, Hong Kah North and Yuhua.

search_results.title: GE2025: Extensive changes to electoral boundaries due to ... - CNA
search_results.content: “Due to population shifts and new housing developments, some EDs (electoral divisions) such as Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC, Sembawang GRC, Tampines GRC, Hong Kah North SMC and Potong Pasir SMC have experienced higher growth than others,” it said. The Punggol estates in Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC were hence carved out and merged with Punggol West SMC to form a new four-member Punggol GRC, the EBRC said. “The committee also recommended reducing the size of Ang Mo Kio GRC, which has the most electors of any ED, by carving out some polling districts to form a new Jalan Kayu SMC,” the EBRC said. “Even with the Tengah estates being absorbed into Chua Chu Kang GRC, the remaining Hong Kah North SMC, comprising Bukit Batok West estates, is still too big and growing,” said the EBRC.

search_results.title: [BREAKING] EBRC released the electoral boundaries for GE2025 - Vulcan Post
search_results.content: The Electoral Boundaries Review Committee (EBRC) in Singapore has announced the electoral boundaries for GE2025 today (March 11, 2025), with a new Group Representation Constiuency (GRC) and an additional Single Member Constiuency, bringing the total to 18 GRCs and 15 SMCs. The Singapore parliament saw PAP winning 83 seats and forming the government, while the Workers Party won a total of ten seats in the 2020 general elections. One of the SMCs which no longer exist for GE2025 is the Bukit Batok SMC, where Singapore Democratic Party’s Secretary-General Dr Chee Soon Juan staked an early claim on earlier last month. The Workers’ Party (WP), with 10 MPs in Parliament, has maintained a strong presence in Hougang SMC since the 1991 General Election and in Aljunied GRC since 2011.

fact_check.explanation: The provided text claims a specific total number of voters (123,557) resulting from the combination of voters from Punggol and a single-member constituency. While the information about GRCs and SMCs is accurate based on the sources, the exact voter numbers seem unverified and could mislead without context. Therefore, there's a moderate level of misinformation due to potential inaccuracies in the voter count.

search_results.title: Here are all the new GRCs for GE2025 - Mothership.SG
search_results.content: The Electoral Boundaries Review Committee (EBRC) released its report today (Mar. 11), recommending several electoral boundary changes in the lead up to the General Election (GE). According to a White Paper on the report of the EBRC published on Mar. 11, the Government has accepted the EBRC’s recommendations and will implement them at the next General Election. For instance, before GE2020, then-Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong directed the Committee to create smaller GRCs and increase the number of SMCs. This year, PM Wong asked the EBRC to "seek to keep the average size of GRCs, the proportion of MPs elected from SMCs, and the average ratio of electors to elected MPs, all at about the same as that in the last General Election".

fact_check.explanation: The statement about the new Pasir Ris-Changi GRC having 100,639 voters, with 87,768 from Pasir Ris-Punggol and 12,871 from East Coast, is corroborated by the source from The Straits Times, which provides accurate information regarding voter distribution in the newly formed electoral constituency. Therefore, there is no misinformation present in this statement.

Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC has been won by the People’s Action Party (PAP) with vote shares between 64 per cent and 73 per cent over the years.
Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean, who anchors the GRC now, has contested there since 2001.
In 2020, it saw a three-cornered fight with the Singapore Democratic Alliance and Peoples Voice, where the PAP came away with a 64.16 per cent victory.
Punggol West SMC, a one-term constituency, was won by PAP’s Ms Sun Xueling with 60.98 per cent of the vote in 2020 against the Workers’ Party’s (WP) Ms Tan Chen Chen.
It had been carved out of Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC then, reducing the six-member constituency to five.
WP may look to contest Punggol GRC in the upcoming election, based on its activity in the area so far.

The only potential inaccuracy is the lack of specific naming of the developments, but this is minor and does not significantly misrepresent the overall fact.

web_research_results.content: It will continue growing, with more housing developments in the pipeline.
In 2020, it had 161,952 voters. This grew to 184,593 voters as at Feb 1.

search_results.title: Fact-checking Joe Biden on voter turnout in 2020 - PolitiFact
search_results.content: PolitiFact | Fact-checking Joe Biden on voter turnout in 2020 Fact-checking Joe Biden on voter turnout in 2020 • As a percentage of the voting eligible population, the turnout rate in 2020 was higher than in any election since 1900. During a high-profile address in Philadelphia on voting rights, President Joe Biden argued that Republican efforts to roll back voting access in some states was unjustified. President-elect Donald Trump posted on X that he is “purchasing TikTok.” stated on October 31, 2024 in a social media post: Former President Donald Trump would “force states to monitor women's pregnancies.” Fact-checking Joe Biden on voter turnout in 2020 stated on February 4, 2025 in social media posts: stated on February 9, 2025 in a Threads post:

search_results.title: Fact check: Table shows outdated voter registration numbers for 15 ...
search_results.content: The Delaware Department of Elections website's General Election 2020 unofficial results page states that as of Nov. 4, 2020 there was a total of 739,570 registered voters, with 507,805 ballots

search_results.title: Flawed Calculation Behind False Claim of Fraudulent Votes
search_results.content: President Donald Trump and tens of thousands of others have shared a false claim on social media that there were “13 MILLION” more votes cast in the 2020 election than eligible voters who participated. In the latest of an unrelenting series of falsehoods on social media about the presidential election, a viral story is erroneously claiming that there were “13 MILLION” more votes counted in the election than the number of eligible voters who participated. “REVEALED: ‘Simple Math’ Shows Biden Claims 13 MILLION More Votes Than There Were Eligible Voters Who Voted in 2020 Election,” its headline reads. But as we said, the Washington Post story estimated that 66.2% of the voting-eligible population (around 239.2 million people, according to the United States Elections Project) voted, not 66.2% of registered voters.

fact_check.explanation: The given text states a specific number of voters but lacks context or a reliable source to verify its accuracy. It does not align with factual voter turnout data provided by official sources like PolitiFact or Reuters, which indicate significantly larger numbers for voter participation in 2020. Without corroboration, this information risks being misleading.

web_research_results.content: The EBRC hence recommended that the Punggol area of the constituency – roughly demarcated by looking north of the Sungei Serangoon Park Connector – merge with Punggol West SMC to form the new Punggol GRC.
This will combine some 96,825 voters in Punggol with 26,732 voters from the single-member constituency for a total of 123,557 voters.

search_results.title: GE2025 electoral boundaries announced: 15 SMCs and 18 GRCs
search_results.content: SINGAPORE - Major changes ahead of Singapore’s next general election will see the creation of one more group representation constituency (GRC) and an additional single-seat ward, bringing the total to 18 GRCs and 15 single-member constituencies (SMC). Explaining its recommendations, the Electoral Boundaries Review Committee (EBRC) said in its report that voter numbers have grown significantly in Pasir Ris-Punggol, Sembawang and Tampines GRCs, as well as the single seats of Hong Kah North and Potong Pasir. Meanwhile, a new five-member Jurong East-Bukit Batok GRC will take in polling districts from the existing Jurong GRC, as well as parts of three SMCs which have been taken off the map – Bukit Batok, Hong Kah North and Yuhua.

search_results.title: GE2025: Extensive changes to electoral boundaries due to ... - CNA
search_results.content: “Due to population shifts and new housing developments, some EDs (electoral divisions) such as Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC, Sembawang GRC, Tampines GRC, Hong Kah North SMC and Potong Pasir SMC have experienced higher growth than others,” it said. The Punggol estates in Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC were hence carved out and merged with Punggol West SMC to form a new four-member Punggol GRC, the EBRC said. “The committee also recommended reducing the size of Ang Mo Kio GRC, which has the most electors of any ED, by carving out some polling districts to form a new Jalan Kayu SMC,” the EBRC said. “Even with the Tengah estates being absorbed into Chua Chu Kang GRC, the remaining Hong Kah North SMC, comprising Bukit Batok West estates, is still too big and growing,” said the EBRC.

search_results.title: [BREAKING] EBRC released the electoral boundaries for GE2025 - Vulcan Post
search_results.content: The Electoral Boundaries Review Committee (EBRC) in Singapore has announced the electoral boundaries for GE2025 today (March 11, 2025), with a new Group Representation Constiuency (GRC) and an additional Single Member Constiuency, bringing the total to 18 GRCs and 15 SMCs. The Singapore parliament saw PAP winning 83 seats and forming the government, while the Workers Party won a total of ten seats in the 2020 general elections. One of the SMCs which no longer exist for GE2025 is the Bukit Batok SMC, where Singapore Democratic Party’s Secretary-General Dr Chee Soon Juan staked an early claim on earlier last month. The Workers’ Party (WP), with 10 MPs in Parliament, has maintained a strong presence in Hougang SMC since the 1991 General Election and in Aljunied GRC since 2011.

fact_check.explanation: The provided text claims a specific total number of voters (123,557) resulting from the combination of voters from Punggol and a single-member constituency. While the information about GRCs and SMCs is accurate based on the sources, the exact voter numbers seem unverified and could mislead without context. Therefore, there's a moderate level of misinformation due to potential inaccuracies in the voter count.

web_research_results.content: “This will also better reflect the identity of the estates in Punggol town,” said the committee.
The remaining polling districts from Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC will merge with the Loyang and Flora estates from East Coast GRC.
This new Pasir Ris-Changi GRC will have 100,639 voters – 87,768 from Pasir Ris-Punggol and 12,871 from East Coast.

search_results.title: New Punggol and Pasir Ris-Changi GRCs in north-east, following rapid ...
search_results.content: The existing five-member Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC will be split into two new four-member GRCs, with a new Punggol GRC created by carving out estates in Punggol and merging those with Punggol West SMC. There was higher growth in Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC, Sembawang GRC, Tampines GRC, Hong Kah North SMC and Potong Pasir SMC due to population shifts and new housing developments, it said. This new Pasir Ris-Changi GRC will have 100,639 voters – 87,768 from Pasir Ris-Punggol and 12,871 from East Coast. With the changes to the Jurong area, a new Jurong Central SMC will be formed to maintain the new Jurong East-Bukit Batok GRC’s number of voters at a level suitable for a five-member constituency.

search_results.title: Electoral Boundaries Review 2025: Major changes with only 5 GRCs, 4 ...
search_results.content: *   Netizens slam Goh Meng Seng’s PPP for Anti-LGBTQ stance and ignoring cost of living in Nee Soon GRC bid *   Singapore launches Youth Charter amid anticipation of general election in May *   Chan Chun Sing defends EBRC’s independence amid questions on transparency *   Dr Tan Cheng Bock confirms plan to contest in General Election 2025 *   People’s Power Party withdraws from People’s Alliance for Reform ahead of GE2025 *   Analysts call Budget 2025 ‘feel-good’ and generous, but netizens remain sceptical

search_results.title: Here are all the new GRCs for GE2025 - Mothership.SG
search_results.content: The Electoral Boundaries Review Committee (EBRC) released its report today (Mar. 11), recommending several electoral boundary changes in the lead up to the General Election (GE). According to a White Paper on the report of the EBRC published on Mar. 11, the Government has accepted the EBRC’s recommendations and will implement them at the next General Election. For instance, before GE2020, then-Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong directed the Committee to create smaller GRCs and increase the number of SMCs. This year, PM Wong asked the EBRC to "seek to keep the average size of GRCs, the proportion of MPs elected from SMCs, and the average ratio of electors to elected MPs, all at about the same as that in the last General Election".

fact_check.explanation: The statement about the new Pasir Ris-Changi GRC having 100,639 voters, with 87,768 from Pasir Ris-Punggol and 12,871 from East Coast, is corroborated by the source from The Straits Times, which provides accurate information regarding voter distribution in the newly formed electoral constituency. Therefore, there is no misinformation present in this statement.

web_research_results.content: The East Coast polling districts that come under this new constituency are those around Changi Airport and Changi Prison Complex.
Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC has been won by the People’s Action Party (PAP) with vote shares between 64 per cent and 73 per cent over the years.
Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean, who anchors the GRC now, has contested there since 2001.
In 2020, it saw a three-cornered fight with the Singapore Democratic Alliance and Peoples Voice, where the PAP came away with a 64.16 per cent victory.
Punggol West SMC, a one-term constituency, was won by PAP’s Ms Sun Xueling with 60.98 per cent of the vote in 2020 against the Workers’ Party’s (WP) Ms Tan Chen Chen.
It had been carved out of Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC then, reducing the six-member constituency to five.
WP may look to contest Punggol GRC in the upcoming election, based on its activity in the area so far.

Credible - The news site is likely to be reliable and trustworthy. Blacklisted - The news site is likely to be unreliable and untrustworthy. Unreliable - Not much is known about this website, may contain misinformation. Do not mention the credibility rating explicitly, but explain it in the insights.  Blacklisted sites should have reliability of around 0-30, unreliable sites should have reliability of around 30-60, and credible sites should have reliability of around 60-100, with range depending on cross references.

tasks_output.summary: Given a credibility rating of a news site, the content...

The few instances that required fact-checking showed moderate to low misinformation scores, suggesting that while there are some inaccuracies, they are not significant enough to undermine the overall credibility of the site.
